headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the First Quarter 2012 Call for Investors in Republic Services. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. Your host for today's call are Don Slager, President and CEO; Tod Holmes, CFO;
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the First Quarter 2012 Call for Investors in Republic Services. Republic Services is traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol RSG. Your host for today's call are Don Slager, President and CEO; Tod Holmes, CFO; and Ed Lang, Republic's Senior Vice President and Treasurer. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the call over to Mr. Long. Good afternoon, Melissa.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gabby. Welcome, good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. This is something and I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services' first quarter 2012 conference call. Don Slager, our CEO; and Tod Holmes, our CFO, are joining me as we di
componenttext:
Thank you, Gabby. Welcome, good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. This is something and I would like to welcome everyone to Republic Services' first quarter 2012 conference call. Don Slager, our CEO; and Tod Holmes, our CFO, are joining me as we discuss our first quarter performance.
Before we get started, I would like to take a moment to remind everyone that some of the information that we discuss on today's call contains forward-looking statements, which involve risks and uncertainties and may be materially different from actual results. Our SEC filings discuss factors that would cause actual results to differ materially from expectations.
 Additionally, the material that we discuss today is time-sensitive. If in the future you listen to a rebroadcast or recording of this conference call, you should be sensitive to the date of the original call, which is April 26, 2012. Please note that this call is the property of Republic Services, Inc. Any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without the expressed written consent of Republic Services is strictly prohibited. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we discuss Republic Services first quarter performance. Before we get started, I want to acknowledge Tod Holmes' announcement regarding his plan to retire next year. First, I want to sa
componenttext: Thanks, Ed. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us as we discuss Republic Services first quarter performance. Before we get started, I want to acknowledge Tod Holmes' announcement regarding his plan to retire next year. First, I want to say that everyone at Republic has great respect for Tod and we also respect his decision. Fortunately, he has given us a full year to work a smooth transition. Secondly, Tod has built an incredibly capable and talented financial team here at Republic, inclusive of solid financial processes, sound controls, and of course, a strong balance sheet. Tod has been one of the primary architects of the company's success fostering and establishing a lasting culture that is firmly committed to creating cash value for our owners, steadfast management, focused on return on investment with a balanced approach to cash utilization. Additionally, besides his 15 years of service  to Republic and the countless contributions he has made along the way, he has certainly been an invaluable adviser to me in the past 1.5 years. We will save all of our goodbyes and our thank yous for next year, as Tod will be with us for a while and we have plenty of work to do together before we host his retirement party. I'll ask Tod share his thoughts with you.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. As Don said, I've announced my retirement, it's effective May 1, 2013. But it's a pretty simple story here. I turn 65 years old in 2013 and have always planned on retiring then. As part of my contract, I'm required to give the company a 1-yea
componenttext: Thanks, Don. As Don said, I've announced my retirement, it's effective May 1, 2013. But it's a pretty simple story here. I turn 65 years old in 2013 and have always planned on retiring then. As part of my contract, I'm required to give the company a 1-year notice prior to my actual retirement. Therefore, I informed Don and the board of my decision at this week's board meeting. I do want to stress to everyone that I'm fully committed to my job here at Republic. We have a great team, as Don indicated here. And I'm committed to serving Republic over the next 12 months. Don and I, along with other members of the board will be working together to ensure a smooth and seamless transition. So, with that, we'll go ahead and start the call. I'm going to turn it back to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tod. I will now review our first quarter financial performance before discussing our revised guidance for 2012. Revenue of approximately $2 billion, core price growth in the quarter was 0.6% with positive price in both collection and disposal busi
componenttext:
Thanks, Tod. I will now review our first quarter financial performance before discussing our revised guidance for 2012. Revenue of approximately $2 billion, core price growth in the quarter was 0.6% with positive price in both collection and disposal businesses. Disposal includes MSW landfill price of 2.6%. Volumes increased by 0.2%, our first quarter earnings per share was $0.38. Our adjusted free cash flow was $175 million. We repurchased 1 million shares in the first quarter for $31 million. We have approximately $620 million remaining under our authorization to return to our shareholders through 2013. We remain committed to an efficient cash utilization strategy, which includes increasing cash returns to our shareholders through share repurchase and dividends. Total cash returned to the shareholders was approximately $112 million during the first quarter. Some of our operational achievements during the first quarter include: Our safety performance continues to improve with a 4% favorable reduction in our frequency rate. We have closed on $65 million of acquisitions through April, that represents $40 million in an annual run rate revenue, these are highly accretive transactions and we expect to achieve the upper end of our acquisition range of $100 million. We have maintained our return on investment focus from reviewing the acquisition market. We continue to invest in fleet automation and converting the fleet to CNG. During the first quarter, we converted 67 routes to automated vehicles and placed 140 CNG vehicles in service. Our 2012 truck order includes 550 CNG vehicles which is 65% of our total fleet order. We opened our renovated single stream recycling facility in Anaheim, California, which increases our recycling capacity in that market by 50,000 tons per year. 
I would like to thank our field operations for their continued support in executing getting our strategy of achieving profitable growth and maintaining a safe rate environment. Tod and Ed will now update our financial performance.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. First quarter  2012 revenue, as Don indicated, was approximately $2 billion and reflects the following components of internal growth. First, core price growth of 0.6%. This level of core price was in line with our expectations that we spoke t
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. First quarter  2012 revenue, as Don indicated, was approximately $2 billion and reflects the following components of internal growth. First, core price growth of 0.6%. This level of core price was in line with our expectations that we spoke to in February for our first quarter. Core price is positive in both collection and disposal businesses, with slightly higher prices in the disposal business due to landfill MSW price increases of 2.6%. Within that component of our business, our third-party open market landfill customer were increased the price in the range of 4% to 5%. We expected the first half of the year to be below 1% with prices rising modestly in the second half of the year as the impact from higher CPI base pricing takes hold on our restructured customer base. We still expect to see this increase in CPI-based pricing in the second half of the year but we do see pressure on price levels from new business in the open market, and also, retention efforts in the open market and municipal segments. As a result, as Don will describe in more detail later, we now expect the full year 2012 the price to be approximately 1%. 
Our fuel recovery fee was positive 0.5%. The increase in fuel recovery fee relates to an increase in fuel costs. The average price per gallon of diesel increased to $3.97 in the first quarter of 2012 from $3.63 in the prior year, this is an increase of 9%. 
Our commodity revenue decreased was 0.8%. Commodity prices decreased 18% to an average price of $122 a ton in the first quarter of this year from $149 per ton in the prior year. Q1 recycling facility commodity volume of 508,000 tons was up 6.3% from the prior year, and up 5.2% on a same-store basis. This volume increase compared to the prior year, and was in line with our expectation. Our revised 2012 guidance is based upon current commodity prices of $120 per ton compared to our original guidance of $118 per ton. This provides a little bit of a tailwind for reference purposes, a $10 per ton change in commodity values equals approximately $0.03 of EPS. And that also includes the impact on our recycling facility and collection businesses. 
Now turning to volume. Q1 volume increased 20 basis points year-over-year. We continue to see volume improvements in the collection line of business. Q1 collection volume was negative 0.1%, and that improved 10 basis points over Q4 levels. Industrial volume was positive year-over-year, driven by a lot of construction activity, and commercial is only slightly negative. Disposal volumes were down 1.3% versus the prior year, which is made up of MSW taunts at our transfer stations in landfills. This was partially offset by higher levels of landfill special waste volumes. Our Q1 2012 volume performance includes the impact of 1 more work day versus the prior year, which resulted in a 50 basis points increase in revenue. 
Now I'll discuss the first quarter year-over-year margin. First quarter 2012 adjusted EBITDA margin was 28.1% compared to 30.6% in the prior year, a 250 basis points decrease. This decline primarily relates to the following 4 items: First, maintenance and repairs. We saw 90 basis points increase in expense that relates to an increase in the cost of the across our supplier base. The refurbishing of containers versus purchasing new containers, and upfront implementation cost associated with One Fleet maintenance initiative. Our approach to repair versus replace containers results in a higher level of expense, but it's capital efficient and results in a lower total cash cost. We expect to work to discontinue our inventory by the end of the year. Second, fuel. The unfavorable fuel expense increase of 60 basis points was due to the 9% increase in the cost of diesel. Our revised 2012 guidance is based upon current fuel cost of $4.13 per gallon compared to the regional guidance of $3.86 per gallon. For reference purposes, a $0.10 change in diesel fuel for gallon is about $0.01 of EPS, and this also includes the impact of the fuel recovery fees. The third margin factor is the work day increase. There is an approximate 60 basis points increase in expenses as a percentage of revenue associated with the additional work day in the quarter. This impact can be seen in almost all our cost categories, but obviously, it's most notable in the labor expense. This results from the additional expense of servicing our customers 1 more day, where the revenue is on many cases on a fixed fee basis and therefore very little corresponding revenue increase. 
Finally, SG&A expenses. The 80 basis point increase in expense relates to investment in our sales force which occurred throughout last year, and also increased levels of bad debt expense partially offset by a reduction in consulting expenses. The 40 basis point increase in bad debt expense primarily relates to one-time recoveries realized in the prior year. SG&A expense at eleven point twelve two percent of revenue reflects the seasonality of our historically lowest revenue quarter of the year, as well as the highest level of payroll taxes that tend to max out earlier in the year. We expect full year SG&A expense to be slightly about 10% of revenue, which is fairly consistent with the prior year. 
Turning to our DD&A. DD&A as a percentage of revenue was 11.8% this year versus 11.5% in the prior year. The 30 basis point increase in expense relates to a landfill liability adjustment recorded in the current quarter for a site that recently closed. DD&A is higher than capital expenditures as a percentage of revenues due to the amortization of intangibles. 
Now I'll turn the call to Ed who will discuss interest expense, taxes and free cash flow.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tod. First quarter 2012 interest expense was $104 million which included $17 million of noncash amortization. As we previously stated, in the second quarter of 2012, we expect to call the notes due in June 2017. The interest benefit of this financ
componenttext:
Thanks, Tod. First quarter 2012 interest expense was $104 million which included $17 million of noncash amortization. As we previously stated, in the second quarter of 2012, we expect to call the notes due in June 2017. The interest benefit of this financing is included in our full year guidance. 
Our first quarter effective tax rate is favorably impacted by closing out state audits and changes in estimates on certain tax matters. We now expect our full year 2012 tax rate to be approximately 37%, but this will fluctuate by quarter. 
I will now discuss free cash flow. First quarter 2012 adjusted free cash flow was $175 million, which consisted of cash provided by operating activities of $334 million, less property and equipment received of $207 million, plus proceeds from the sale of property of $5 million, plus merger-related expenditures net of tax of $41 million, plus divestiture-related payments of $2 million. Therefore, adjusted free cash flow equals $175 million. Free cash flow timing tends to vary by quarter, in particular due to capital expenditures and changes in working capital. We expect to achieve the lower end of our full year guidance range of $775 million to $800 million. 
Now I'll talk about the balance sheet. At March 31, our accounts receivable balance was $808 million, and our days sales outstanding was 37 days or 23 days net of deferred revenue. Reported debt was approximately $6.9 billion at March 31, and excess credit available under our bank facility was approximately $1.6 billion. 
I will now turn the call back to Don.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed. Now I'll update our 2012 guidance. We expect adjusted free cash flow at the lower end of our original guidance of $775 million to $800 million. Adjusted earnings per share of $1.86 to $1.90, which is down from our original guidance of $1.98 to
componenttext:
Thanks, Ed. Now I'll update our 2012 guidance. We expect adjusted free cash flow at the lower end of our original guidance of $775 million to $800 million. Adjusted earnings per share of $1.86 to $1.90, which is down from our original guidance of $1.98 to $2.02. Our EPS guidance is primarily impacted by lower-than-expected internal growth, higher fuel expense, implementation cost associated with our maintenance initiatives, and certain one-time costs. Our revised guidance assumes a normal seasonal earnings pattern of 47% to 48% in the first half of the year, and the balance in the second half. We expect price to be approximately 1%. We expect full year volume performance to be flat, down from our original guidance of 0.5%. Our volume expectations are being negatively impacted primarily by 3 distinct MSW disposal locations at the large national account contract loss. 
EBITDA margins for the full year of 29.5% compared to our original guidance of 30.5%. We expect our full year tax rate to be approximately 37%. We will remain focused on executing our strategy while improving return on capital through continued disciplined pricing, utilizing our ROI-based tools, growing the business through sales, acquisitions and investments in recycling and processing technology, protecting our profitable business that generates appropriate returns, managing our cost structure through programs designed to gain operational efficiencies, including fleet automation, synergy conversion and standardized managed practices, investing in our people through training and development, and maintaining a safe and positive work environment allowing us to continue to attract and retain top talent. Also enhancing our customer's experience with Republic by continuously improving service delivery and providing solutions to meet their changing demands and buying habits. 
At this time, operator, we'll open the call for questions.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Scott Levine from JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Scott Levine from JPMorgan.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question really would be, it's only been a few months since you said guidance. So what's changed, I'm a little surprised that things changed this quickly, general speaking. So maybe I'll just -- we're not focusing on price or cost or any
componenttext: I guess my first question really would be, it's only been a few months since you said guidance. So what's changed, I'm a little surprised that things changed this quickly, general speaking. So maybe I'll just -- we're not focusing on price or cost or any particular item, just wondering how things could have changed or your view of the world could change this much this quickly?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well I guess we need to talk about price and volume because that is part of it. They are 2 of the major component there. When we built our business plan as we do over year, we kind of consider how we see the world kind of exit speed Q4 and then what we're
componenttext: Well I guess we need to talk about price and volume because that is part of it. They are 2 of the major component there. When we built our business plan as we do over year, we kind of consider how we see the world kind of exit speed Q4 and then what we're seeing at the time, we are finalizing the budget in January and setting guidance and February. At that time, we felt better about the economy than we do today. We thought we'll see more economic lift than we're seeing right now. We thought the pricing environment in the open market improved a little bit, it really hasn't. We maintained -- the cadence of our pricing programs so we're out in the general market, pricing is frequently and is consistently lower last year. Our price to 2 customers was about 2.7% in the quarter. So that's continued. We've seen a continued pressure from the municipal segment in the sort of rollbacks, in renewing business, that's pretty consistent with what we thought. And then the fleet initiative has cost us a little more than we figured. So we talked about that quite a bit that, Scott, in 2010, we decided we needed to focus more on fleet, we're I think the 8th largest locational fleet in the nation. And to take the customer service insurance and it's productivity to the next level, we need to run our fleet consistently across the nation, we saw some disparity on how fleets were operating. And so we designed this one fleet program, we guided last year we began to roll it out with that. And we've gone now and brought into that initiative here in the early part of '12. And what you're seeing is, the real main focus there, the fleet initiative is the move more to scheduled maintenance and less reactive maintenance to get to that level of productivity in customer service we're trying to achieve. And in order to do that, we've got to spend additional money that's sort of a temporary adjustment, a little bit of a bowel, if you will, to move to the level of a kind of a world class maintenance, where we run our fleet at. So rather than back off of it, we've decided to move forward with it, even though it's going to cost us more this year, we're coming to you and let you know that it's critical enough for us to adjust our guidance, we're going to move to the initiative over the next 3 years and become a world class fleet.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Scott, where we look at it, obviously, as Don said, we saw this volume situation here late in the quarter, and then this quarter, early in the fourth quarter here in April. And again, when you look at the cost, as Don indicated, we think that we were seei
componenttext: Scott, where we look at it, obviously, as Don said, we saw this volume situation here late in the quarter, and then this quarter, early in the fourth quarter here in April. And again, when you look at the cost, as Don indicated, we think that we were seeing about 90 basis points of cost increases, kind of about year-over-year basis. And so that is probably around $0.12. And it's really, as Don said, 3 big item. We've got the maintenance, which is the truck itself, so the container maintenance which is probably worth about 5 to 10 basis points, which we'll work through this year. So while the maintenance might be with us for a couple of years, the container is probably just this year. We've got that fuel, which everyone is aware of, which is about $0.03 of earnings and an additional $0.04 of maintenance. And then we have landfill, we've got higher leachate because of the warm weather in the Northeast. And we also had some other close site cost, one particular landfill, which we think are kind of either current quarter or current year situation that should mitigate next year.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: We've also seen 4 distinct volume impact since we set our guidance that equal that 50 basis points.
componenttext: We've also seen 4 distinct volume impact since we set our guidance that equal that 50 basis points.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And maybe as my follow-up. Just to kind of understand this and really reconcile the change in guidance with the business environment that you're seeing. So it sounds like most of the revision is internal and programmatic as opposed to the bu
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And maybe as my follow-up. Just to kind of understand this and really reconcile the change in guidance with the business environment that you're seeing. So it sounds like most of the revision is internal and programmatic as opposed to the business climate being what it is. But maybe if you could separate the business climate and from the program spending and talk a little bit about, it sounds frankly you got more guarded on the business environment as the quarters progressed. Is that an accurate interpretation? How conservative should we think about your guidance being with regard to the business environment, which from macro perspective seems to be stable, if not improving a little bit?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say, we got $0.38 of earnings in the first quarter. And we think our guidance is realistic. Again, as Don indicated, and we said this repeatedly, our businesses fairly predictable and we get about 46% to 48% of the earnings in the first half
componenttext: Yes, I would say, we got $0.38 of earnings in the first quarter. And we think our guidance is realistic. Again, as Don indicated, and we said this repeatedly, our businesses fairly predictable and we get about 46% to 48% of the earnings in the first half of the year, and then 52% to 54% in the second half of the year. So early April, as we were closing of the first quarter, what we're seeing there was, what we're seeing in the competitive environment here in April as well is kind of a flat or economy than what we were expecting, led us to conclude that we weren't going to get the lift on the economy, and the competitive landscape was remaining maybe a little bit more competitive than we originally thought, whether it's in volume or in price, both these categories.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012

componenttext: And our next question comes from Corey Greendale from First Analysis.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: So the first question, I guess, just a little bit more on the competitive environment. So is there any change in how you would describe your behavior as far as you're viewing price competitively?
componenttext: So the first question, I guess, just a little bit more on the competitive environment. So is there any change in how you would describe your behavior as far as you're viewing price competitively?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Corey, I think, I mean, we talked about this a lot, and I mentioned in my early comment. Our price to customers is running about 2.7%. And as always churn at the business. There's always a competitive business. So all that churn and mix and service increa
componenttext:
Corey, I think, I mean, we talked about this a lot, and I mentioned in my early comment. Our price to customers is running about 2.7%. And as always churn at the business. There's always a competitive business. So all that churn and mix and service increase, decrease, new account, lost account, we end up posting this 6% price. We are still actively pricing in the marketplace. If you look at our landfill pricing, prized in the open market MSW's 45%. So for those people using our landfills, in the open market, they're seeing continuously a 45% increase. So that's continuing. Having said that, we're not really gaining new accounts in the landfill and we probably lost more open market landfill accounts than we gained. Because we're not subsidized competition. We're going to continue to raise landfill prices because the colossal of owning people's trash is an item, you can't solve that by volume, you got to charge that certain amount to get that return. So we've continued that consistent strategy and we're not going to change. Open market, we have an RPM pricing program. As we've talked about in the open market, about 1/12 of our customers receive the price increase in the open market we work through our view of the cost and we look at what we think price elasticity is and we price our business. We also then have to go through a continuous effort of defending business, we got a good business, a high margin business, so we got to defend, and we use our ROI tools and we have what we call a walk-away price. At some point, we won't keep a customer for less than we think is a reason, but we do defend vigorously. So our actions have not changed from that perspective. One thing we started talking about last year, and that is understanding by market who is taking share at our expense. And today, we are very good at understanding by market who is taking share at our expense, and we have a sales staff that is targeted at saving business from those, call it, predators. And also making sure that we're selling accordingly into the lines of business, because we can't just simply watch or leave as the total pie really isn't growing very much. So that all impacts churn. But again, we're very consistently using our ROI tools, our whole strategy and our compensation program, and personally, the odd and pie philosophy is very grounded in ROI. But we've got a good -- we always fight a good competitive fight. 
On the volume side, I mentioned 50 basis points of volume that we expected to maintain, and has already gone away in the year. We lost a large national account, which is about $25 million reported revenue this year or about 30 basis points of that 50 basis points. And -- then we've lost 3 -- or we know we've lost 2 disposal contracts that we contact with municipalities. Those were based on price, so they decided to undercut us on the price. And we're really to lower our price landfill for that business. The last piece of that is, as you guys were familiar with LA, the Point Hills landfill has got a scheduled closing date, they have gotten even more aggressive on attracting volume because they're going to walk away from their space. And so that market  has just further been depressed over the last 30 or 60 days, and so we just can't close our eyes to those volume adjustments, those volumes are gone and we don’t naturally think we can make them up, we're not going to chase volume to do that. We've got to be reasonable and responsible. So a long answer to your question, Corey, but I think our approach to business has not changed. We may be tougher than ever as far as defending business. And we're certainly a little more prescriptive [ph] understanding who is taking share at our expense.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012

componenttext: I think that the majority of it is, I would say the fuel and fuel related which is maybe about 1/3 of that 90 basis points could be with us on an ongoing basis. The other items, which are about 60 basis points would be either dropping off this year, or in the case of our fleet initiative, that's probably about -- that's like a 13 and 14 type of timeframe for us. That will continue on as we roll through our larger into our shops smaller shops across the country. That's a multi-year situation. But again, we should be harvesting the value out of that here, through fuel load calls and a more efficient fleet in the future.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: The predators that you referred to, Don, could you give us a feel of them becoming more predatory, more competitive, recently. And if so, is it a jurisdiction that that's going to continue or do you think they're eventually going to have to get more disci
componenttext: The predators that you referred to, Don, could you give us a feel of them becoming more predatory, more competitive, recently. And if so, is it a jurisdiction that that's going to continue or do you think they're eventually going to have to get more disciplined given their own cost pressures?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't speak for them. I don't think necessarily the small haulers have gotten more competitive or more active. Again, the whole pie really isn't growing. So they want to keep their trucks on the street. We are -- one of the things we're adjusting
componenttext: Well, I can't speak for them. I don't think necessarily the small haulers have gotten more competitive or more active. Again, the whole pie really isn't growing. So they want to keep their trucks on the street. We are -- one of the things we're adjusting our guidance off is fuel, we're paying $4.16 a gallon for fuel today. Some of the small haulers like to sell no fees. And I don't know how they adjust their pricing, and make any money if they're not raising prices at some point, with this high fuel cost. So we'd like to think that we see more price activity there, but again, I can't speak on their behalf. So and we have seen some spots in some markets where things have gotten more competitive by I would say across the board, both large and small, even a couple of national companies that maybe overly optimistic in a couple of spots. I mentioned those couple big MSW disposal contracts we've lost, we're little surprised that the rates that those contracts were let forth. So the national I spoke off, our margins were very, very thin there. We enjoyed a 7-year relationship with Tod Holmes at national account, we've got continued to reduce their price until their efficiency, recycle more waste and we're a little surprise by what happened there. And when we met with them, it was just strictly price issue. And we just weren't willing to lower price any further. We're going to continue to be diligent raising prices. As I said before, we're going to use safeguard our infrastructure, we're not going to give it away to undercapitalize competitors. And we're going to continue to fight hard for the marketplace that's the state of the business. And obviously I think a lot of this is resolved, if the economy does take off and some of the things you read about actually come true, but we don't have that crystal ball. So if the economy improves, we think market behavior improves, and then we think we all win from that.

componenttext: Yes, I think it tax planning. I think it's succession planning. And -- we've got many, many stories from some of our sellers. They want to move on to different part of their life. They're concerned about taxes and the change in tax law. There's a lot of different stores there. But we think it's a robust pipeline. And as I said before, we think we can take advantage of kind of a steady diet of acquisitions over the next several years, around the $100 million year range at a very good multiple, it's a very good use of our cash and there's a very nice businesses out there that we're going to be looking at in that period of time. So we've got a lot of good success and we will continue that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can we talk a little bit about the things that are happening in the macro marketplace, I'm probably going to exceed my 2 question things as we do this, but let's try. We're hearing special waste activity has now settled into normal routine special waste X
componenttext: Can we talk a little bit about the things that are happening in the macro marketplace, I'm probably going to exceed my 2 question things as we do this, but let's try. We're hearing special waste activity has now settled into normal routine special waste X stimulus driven, if you're in the right geographies, there is filled activity. MSW is kind of down a level but it's not really recovering, it's just kind of hanging when you listen to other calls and talk to private players and what have-you. . What's your view of that kind of environment?

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. Special waste is good for us, it's relatively flat to last year. We are getting our fair share of the national gas drilling waste. Again, 2 or 3 years ago, we had no revenue from that business, today it's a nice little business for us, we fo
componenttext: Yes, Michael. Special waste is good for us, it's relatively flat to last year. We are getting our fair share of the national gas drilling waste. Again, 2 or 3 years ago, we had no revenue from that business, today it's a nice little business for us, we focus on it. But as you said, we're not in all geographies. So what's going on in North Dakota is kind of the lead stories in the headline, but we're not in North Dakota so we don't take advantage of that volume. The roll out business has been decent for us, we've talked about the industrial-strength that we saw last year and coming through Q4. We just have that stronger. People ask me, what about automotive and frankly we're not a big player in automotive. The margins in that business tend to be very small, automotive companies tend to be sort of very aggressive purchasers of the services. And if not, then a big segment for us so why can't we speak to. Construction, we had a good seasonal -- I mean, more than expected seasonal activity in Q1, but we also had no winter. So we're not going to hang our hat on that thinking that's the baseline to go forward from. We have -- we think some belief that some of that was pull forward, within jobs like construction, put some early spring cleanup. So we're not so sure about what that means yet for the year. We don't really see  true seasonality until May and June and that's when we get tell you what's happening there. Commercial is kind of flattish, still a little bit down and we have improving volume sequential quarters in the Collection business. We just have been built top and turned positive yet. So I don't think -- I know the economy is getting worse, but it's not -- of the and it certainly not getting as we posted up our guidance, we thought it was getting a little better at a more rapid rate. So some of this is about velocity of change. And we're just -- we're not willing to go further in the year with our formal guidance, based on what you're seeing today.

componenttext: The maintenance question was not really, this is something that has continued to have all as we've gone from of view pilot location to a broader rollout.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, that is the thing to understand here, Mike. We fanned out here, right? We've gained speed and traction so we went from a handful of facilities and now we're multiplying more facilities, we're touching and that's why were started to see this string ra
componenttext: Yes, that is the thing to understand here, Mike. We fanned out here, right? We've gained speed and traction so we went from a handful of facilities and now we're multiplying more facilities, we're touching and that's why were started to see this string ramp up and again. We could make good choices right. We could say, hey, stop, slow down. But again, as I said earlier, we believe we got to get through this. We believe -- when you look at our operating cost, we have strong margins, we're good operators, to get to the next level of efficiency and cost experience, we need to have better fleet reliability. That part of that is moving too, as I said, or programmatic maintenance and plan maintenance versus reactive maintenance. And that means they've got to sort of move through, that faith and so there's a little bit of sort of maintenance catch up to get you to that point where your fleet availability up time improves, your road calls decreased and you really do plan maintenance. So that's a lot of work, it's a real high touch real high change, change management process, but we don't think we can put it off. We think we need to move through them thing is going to pay dividends in a lot of ways. Customer experience productivity, drive them given frankly mechanic retention. Mechanics are hard to come by, good mechanics want to work for company that takes maintenance seriously the way we are. And it's all going to pay dividends when the take some time. And we've got to make the investment. I think is the right thing to do. And we didn't feel it was a good thing to say hey, this is harder than we thought, more expensive. Let's stop and think that front would have negatively impact of the morale of the business and the future of the business.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Mike, you have a good question there in terms of our visibility, I guess, a couple of months ago. And again, when you look at this. We've got an impact of about $0.06 in price. And that's something that's really just emerged here, I would say in the last
componenttext: Mike, you have a good question there in terms of our visibility, I guess, a couple of months ago. And again, when you look at this. We've got an impact of about $0.06 in price. And that's something that's really just emerged here, I would say in the last 30 days to 45 days at the most. And then the volume is the same sort of thing. I mean, that's a very current thing that we're realizing, the commodities obviously is a positive, that's about $0.03. And then when you look at this $0.12 of cost increase, the fuel we didn't anticipate, we are very explicit in the guidance there. I think the maintenance for containers was something, as Don indicated, is something that has evolved recently and the container maintenance is just a smart thing to do from a cash standpoint. So a lot of these costs are things that are more current in nature. Now we also have some positive things. Our original tax guidance was 39%. And interest also, I think, the credit markets are probably a little bit more favorable. So we've got a little bit of benefit, we think on taxes and also on interest. And in fact, we've got a number of open tax years. We have 3 cycles, we've got some other planning issues and opportunities. So we may do a little bit better than that. But again, these are things that have recently unfolded. And we frankly, Don and I talked about, should we adjust the guidance now? Or should we wait until mid-summer, which is our traditional practice. And our feeling was the $0.38 first quarter and our knowledge that something dramatic would have to change in the second half of the year to meet the guidance, and the fact is, there's a rhythm to the quarterly earnings in this business, absent some external influence, we felt that it was appropriate to be upfront and direct to the guidance rather than waiting until July.

And there's a couple of decisions that we made continue to spend a purple initiatives.

componenttext: And one other things I'd say in the cost side, is the landfill cost are up, we saw a lot of leachate in the Midwest and Northeast. And we felt that one-time item, it doesn't necessarily mean that it's going to be lower later on. So that's in our guidance also.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, you know what, great question. So the plan is we have today is we would impact 40% of our fleet this year, right? It would be landing in the divisions that represent 40% of our trucks, another 30% in '13, another 30% in '14. We may have slowed that
componenttext: Okay, you know what, great question. So the plan is we have today is we would impact 40% of our fleet this year, right? It would be landing in the divisions that represent 40% of our trucks, another 30% in '13, another 30% in '14. We may have slowed that depending on progress, but that's rough numbers, right? So what we're seeing is kind of a 9-month hill decline there of some additional expense to get to that promised land of scheduled maintenance and so on. And so that's what we're experiencing. And we are seeing that in Q1 and we think that's how it's going to progress throughout the year. So that's it. With 3 years, we'll be through it, then we'll be gaining benefits throughout the rollout at some point as these division gets certified and are operating at a new level of performance we'll begin to benefit from the productivity gains and so on and so forth. Some of our test divisions have been through last year, we've seen the improvement in things like inventory, drive overall, the benefits some of them softer than others, but that's the cadence we're on.

componenttext: The other thing I would say, Bill, we're managing the business for the long-term. We know this is the right thing to do. And while it's difficult to swallow, this additional $18 million, $19 million of cost this year, it's important that we stay the course and we're committed to that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: No pullback. Again, we do believe that the waste stream is changing, that customer demand is changing. And remind everybody, some very interesting things that we look at that are very global macro across the whole company. But when you look at investing i
componenttext: No pullback. Again, we do believe that the waste stream is changing, that customer demand is changing. And remind everybody, some very interesting things that we look at that are very global macro across the whole company. But when you look at investing in the business and recycling, we look very distinctly of the marketplace. So we have 240 distinct unique markets across Republic Services. And those markets are changing at different speeds. And it's our job to understand what's changing in the philosophy to change. So we have, earmarked again, about 10% of those market or 25 markets that we think will invest in over the next 5 years. And it's kind of a dynamic list, there's some things moving up and down and that list of over 25. But we're on track to make investments in about 5 market this year, as I said, we just completed Q1 renovation of our Anaheim facility which will increase our recycling capacity there. Our recycling tons in total are up in Q1, 5% same-store, right? So that's that is part of the business that's growing. And we can't deny that customer demand is changing it and we need to be in that space. So we can provide all the solutions that our customers need and we're committed to doing that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: As you can appreciate, we entered into the business plan and we have contracts that are being renewed. And we have to look at trends in the business, where that's a look at how far we think we are along an extension negotiation, and we've got sort of a bu
componenttext: As you can appreciate, we entered into the business plan and we have contracts that are being renewed. And we have to look at trends in the business, where that's a look at how far we think we are along an extension negotiation, and we've got sort of a budget in amount. We think we're going to retain X% of these customers we already know we're on the path to retain certain ones, some are more at risk and we budget for certain amount of business loss, business days, service reduction, we have to obviously take a stab at that. In the case of this large national store, again, as I said, we have a 7-year relationship that we thought was very strong. We've done a good for the client. And we put our budget together, we were convinced, frankly, the we're going to extend the business based on the work we've done, and we were wrong. There was something else afoot, and there was somebody with dramatically different pricing structure apparently, than we had. That happens, and that's the nature of that.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: The other thing, I would say is, we've got a very strong first discipline for either bids or acquisitions, which we've applied to this large account. We know what our investment is, we know what the returns are. And with an existing customer, we would wan
componenttext: The other thing, I would say is, we've got a very strong first discipline for either bids or acquisitions, which we've applied to this large account. We know what our investment is, we know what the returns are. And with an existing customer, we would want to retain it, so we might stretch it because we know the risks. We know that what the waste stream is. But when you get to the point where it becomes a little bit irrational, we have to have a walk away, and that's what we do.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: And when you're incumbent, you tend to know all the cost. And so we still believe in the national accounts business, we've got a decent pipeline of opportunities, both nationally and regionally that we're working. And we've got many, many national account
componenttext: And when you're incumbent, you tend to know all the cost. And so we still believe in the national accounts business, we've got a decent pipeline of opportunities, both nationally and regionally that we're working. And we've got many, many national account clients that are working very diligently and on managing their waste stream and so forth. So we're continuing to do the work and it's just again, as we said before, it's a competitive business, it always has been, it always will be. And sometimes, a couple of these things take us by surprise.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Then finally, sorry for the multiple question part. But on the margin front, for an EBITDA in particular, given some of these fall offs and walk away from contract issues. I would suggest given that multiyear contracts or relationships that lack of volume
componenttext: Then finally, sorry for the multiple question part. But on the margin front, for an EBITDA in particular, given some of these fall offs and walk away from contract issues. I would suggest given that multiyear contracts or relationships that lack of volume in the market, that the opportunity for margin expansion beyond even 12 at the moment is going to be something you get your work cut out for you.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, remember what Don said earlier. We have a whole series of other initiatives that will give us what your margin potential. So when you look at automation, when you look at CNG, when we look at this maintenance initiative, which headwind. So there are
componenttext: Well, remember what Don said earlier. We have a whole series of other initiatives that will give us what your margin potential. So when you look at automation, when you look at CNG, when we look at this maintenance initiative, which headwind. So there are some productivity operating opportunities there, and we are continuing to price increase. Some of what we're seeing on the margins is kind of short term in the quarter, which affects the full year, some are kind of annual and basis in the mid to the situation in fuel, it's a little bit longer time. But there are opportunities to expand the margin.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Alan, I mentioned in my comments, our safety frequency improved by 4% again in the quarter, we've deployed more automation, we ended last year at 59% of our fleet was automated, our goal this year is to get it to 63%, I think. Ultimately we'll get i
componenttext: Sure. Alan, I mentioned in my comments, our safety frequency improved by 4% again in the quarter, we've deployed more automation, we ended last year at 59% of our fleet was automated, our goal this year is to get it to 63%, I think. Ultimately we'll get it over 80%. We're going to continue to invest accordingly and that CNG is a good investment for us. Our overall headcount in Q1 was less than it was in Q4. So we're obviously good cost managers, we are tracking those kind of metrics across the business, and the strategy really the company hasn't changed, and that's right.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: And its all the time we have for questions today. I'll now turn the call back to Mr. Slater for his closing remarks.
componenttext: And its all the time we have for questions today. I'll now turn the call back to Mr. Slater for his closing remarks.

headline: Republic Services, Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Gabbie. In closing, I'd like to thank the entire Republic team for their continued hard work and dedication in the first quarter. We remain focused on the business fundamentals required to improve our return on invested capital and furthe
componenttext: Well, thank you, Gabbie. In closing, I'd like to thank the entire Republic team for their continued hard work and dedication in the first quarter. We remain focused on the business fundamentals required to improve our return on invested capital and further position our company to grow across all lines of business. As a reminder, a recording of this call will be available through May 3, 2012 by calling (203) 369-1833 and using a passcode of 4589. Additionally, I want to point out that our SEC filings, our earnings press release, which includes GAAP reconciliation tables and a discussion of business activities, along with a recording of this call, are all available on Republic's website at republicservices.com. And finally, I want to remind you that Republic's management team routinely participates in investor conferences. When presentations are scheduled, the dates and times are posted on our website, along with instructions for listening to the live web. Thank you for spending time with us today, and have a good evening.
